column1: Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease is a group of disorders passed down through families that affect the nerves outside the brain and spine.

They may include: - Foot deformity (very high arch to feet) - Foot drop (inability to hold foot horizontal) - Loss of lower leg muscle, which leads to skinny calves - Numbness in the foot or leg - "Slapping" gait (feet hit the floor hard when walking) - Weakness of the hips, legs, or feet Later, similar symptoms may appear in the arms and hands, which may include a claw-like hand.

A physical exam may show: - Difficulty lifting up the foot and making toe-out movements (foot drop) - Lack of stretch reflexes in the legs - Loss of muscle control and atrophy (shrinking of the muscles) in the foot or leg - Thickened nerve bundles under the skin of the legs A muscle biopsy or nerve biopsy may confirm the diagnosis.
Eventually the disease may cause disability.
